parts: Name this Belgian surrealist who also made works such as Golconda and The Menaced Assassin.
In addition to This is Not an Apple, Magritte also painted this work that has the phrase, “This is not a pipe” written in French.
Another of Magritte’s most influential paintings is this painting which depicts a daytime street and a single lit street-lamp.

answers: “The year in which Ford’s first Model T rolled off his assembly line” [or any description about the Model T hitting the market or selling Model Ts, prompt until you get “Model T”]
parts: Name this book about Bernard and Lenina’s visit to a Savage reservation where they encounter John the Savage.
Brave New World is takes place in 632 A.F. The A.F. refers to the numbers of years after this event occurred. Description acceptable.

Brave New World gets its title from this work. This Shakespearean play has more music than any other of his plays, and composers such as Jean Sibelius, Hector Berlioz, and Engelbert Humperdinck have written incidental music for it.
Give this adjective that describes things related to the conic section exemplified by the function f$(x) = \frac{1}{x}$ [“f of x equals one over x”].

Surfaces such as the saddle, which have a hyperbolic geometry, do not satisfy this postulate from Euclid’s Elements, since two lines on such a surface that locally have the namesake property will diverge.
The hyperbolic sine is this type of function, which can be represented mathematically by the relation sinh(-x) = -sinh(x) [“sinch of negative x equals negative sinch of x”].
John B. Watson classically conditioned a young boy to associate the beating of a hammer on metal with the presence of this animal, unethically neglecting to rid the boy of his acquired fears.

This series of experiments conducted by Albert Bandura involved conditioning participants to engage in violent behavior after they witnessed the namesake object pop back up every time it was hit or knocked down.
This Swarthmore College psychologist did not receive informed consent in his conformity study in which participants were asked to match the lengths of geometric lines.
Clara Barton adopted this occupation at the onset of the Civil War. Her work in this occupation would later be an inspiration in the formation of the American Red Cross.

Dorothea Dix, another Civil War nurse, rather made her name in the creation of the first generation of these establishments in the mid-1800s. Dix helped create the Harrisburg State Hospital in 1851, Pennsylvania’s first one of these establishments.

This woman also was educated as a nurse; however, she is far better known as a pioneering activist in birth control legislation. This woman’s American Birth Control League later became the Planned Parenthood Federation of America in 1942.

Name this equation named after a German physical chemist, which can be used to calculate quantities associated with half-cell or fuel-cell reactions such as the activity, temperature, and electromotive force.
Oxidation occurs at this end of a cell, in which conventional current flows into a half cell.

A quantity symbolized nu and known as this word prefixed with “over” occurs in variants of the Nernst equation because heat loss makes reactions less efficient. A quantity symbolized mu and known as the “chemical” type of this quantity can be used to derive the Nernst equation.
Name this melodic framework for improvisation that is the Indian Classical equivalent of the Western musical modes.
Rāga occur in this South Indian style of classical music, which is contrasted with Hindustani by its emphasis on vocal expertise.
The drone in both Carnatic and Hindustani music is usually provided by this long-necked plucked instrument that plays buzzing, overtone-rich fifths.

answers: Black Tezcatlipoca [do not accept or prompt on Smoking Mirror]
Xipe Totec [do not prompt on Red Tezcatlipoca or the Flayed One]
parts: Name this smoking mirror, who was knocked out of the sky with a stone. This deity then turned into a Jaguar and destroyed that world.
This other deity, known as the Red Tezcatlipoca, was depicted being flayed. People would often touch the flayed skin of those sacrificed to this deity to cure their ailments.
In human sacrifices to Xipe Totec, a sacrificial knife made of obsidian or this fire-producing material was used to remove the victim’s heart and flay them.

Name this Dutch Nobel laureate who names the set of transformation equations used in Einstein’s theory of special relativity. He also is the namesake the force felt by a charged particle in an electromagnetic field.
Edward Norton Lorenz lends his name to a particular type of the “strange” version of this thing, a set of chaotic solutions that evolve from varied initial conditions.
Konrad Lorenz helped pioneer the field of modern ethology by studying this instinctive behavior in graylag geese, in which they bond with the first moving object they see after hatching.
Give this term which described the pre-unification state of the seven Anglo-Saxon kingdoms.
This member of the Heptarchy had its capital at York. Notable kings include Kings Aethelfrith and Oswald.
One king of Northumbria was this man who adopted Roman Christianity. This son of Aethelfrith was the victor at the Battle of Winwaed where he overthrew Penda of Mercia.
Name this character who chooses to stay silent and receive no land, unlike Regan and Goneril.
This king dies in Cordelia’s arms, and also gives his name to the play in which he appears.

In a similar work by the Brothers Grimm, the elder daughters flatter the king, while the youngest brings him a decorated container of this substance. The king was so sad that she only loved him more than this substance that he demanded her execution.
Name this artist behind works such as Crack is Wack, Boxers, and Ignorance=Fear. He was known for using stick-figure-like people in his works.
Haring’s work Boxers was a work of this artform. Other famous examples of this include Cloud Gate and an untitled work known as the Chicago Picasso.
The Chicago Picasso depicts a single one of these body-parts at its center. The Portrait of Adele Bloch-Bauer I features the titular woman with a dress covered in these.

answers: “The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County” [or “The Notorious Jumping Frog of Calaveras County”, or “Jim Smiley and His Jumping Frog”]
parts: Name this short story in which Simon Wheeler tells the story of the title animal named Dan’l Webster, who does not budge when a stranger pours lead shot into his mouth.

In this short story, an unnamed Manhattan lawyer tells the story of the title character, who begins working as a legal document copier along with Nippers and Turkey and eventually responds to everybody’s requests by saying, “I would prefer not to.”
In this short story by Bret Harte, Oakhurst, Stumpy, and other gold prospectors raise a baby boy whose mother dies in childbirth, but that boy eventually dies along with Kentuck in a flash flood.
Name this member of the Black Hand who failed to assassinate Franz Ferdinand, and blew up the car behind him instead.
This eventual assassin of Franz Ferdinand was unable to act after the initial failure by Cabrinovic. He was imprisoned and eventually died of tuberculosis in his cell.
The assassination took place in this city. Military troops from this city supposedly were not present because it would offend the local citizenry.
Name this South American nation home to a majority of the Atacama Desert, with its capital at Santiago.

Chile maintains possession of this distant Pacific Island known as Isla de Pascua in Spanish. The introduction of the Polynesian rat is in part responsible for the massive decline in the indigenous population on this island.

This city, aside from being the country’s fifth most populated metropolitan area, was home to Chile’s first public library and the longest continuously published Spanish newspaper. This city is also the name of a Lutheran university in northeastern Indiana with a crusader as a mascot.

answers: resignation from the papacy [or stepping down or equivalents] <McMaken>
parts: Name this current Bishop of Rome who is the first Jesuit Pope and the first Pope from the Americas.
Pope Francis was the Archbishop of the capital city of this country. The Metropolitan Cathedral in that city also houses the remains of General José de San Martín.
Pope Francis was elected by the conclave after this action occurred with Pope Benedict XVI [“the sixteenth”] in 2013. This action has not happened since 1415 with Pope Gregory XII [“the twelfth”].

answers: “all men are created equal” [exact answer required]
parts: Give this five-word phrase from the U.S. Declaration of Independence that is said to be a self-evident truth.
Ho Chi Minh convinced this emperor to abdicate. This last emperor of Vietnam also was responsible for officially adopting the name “Vietnam,” formally replacing “Annam.”
Bao Dai was the final emperor of this final ruling family of Vietnam. Other members of this dynasty include Gia Long and Minh Mang.

answers: it was anchored in place [accept anything about it not being able to move] <Yoshida>
parts: Name these things, other examples of which include Naxos and Milos.
Another famous mythological island is this island, upon which Leto gave birth to Artemis and Apollo. It was mostly barren.
After Leto gave birth, this fate befell Delos. Description acceptable.
Name this maximal load of a population in a local environment, which in population dynamics is symbolized K.

In contrast to K-selection, species that exhibit this form of selection exploit less-crowded ecological niches and produce many offspring that have lower chances of survival. The name for this type of selection refers to the term in the Verhulst model that describes the maximum growth rate.
The aforementioned Verhulst model consists of a differential equation describing this type of curve. This function, a type of sigmoid curve, runs from zero to the carrying capacity in an “S” shape.

answers: “How Much Land Does a Man Need?” [or “How Much Land Does a Man Require?” or “Mnoga li cheloveku zemli nuzhna?”]
falling while hanging up his curtains [prompt gratuitously and be lenient] <Yoshida>
parts: Name this short story in which Pahom needs to walk around as large an area as he can, so long as he returns to the starting point by sundown. In the end, he runs so hard that he drops dead.
“How Much Land Does a Man Need?” was a story by this man, the author of novellas such as Hadji Murad and The Death of Ivan Ilyich.
In The Death of Ivan Ilyich, Ilyich is a judge with a terminal illness who dies when performing this activity. Description acceptable.
This last work by Mozart was completed by his student, Franz Xaver Sussmayr.
This last opera by Puccini, whose most famous aria is “Nessun Dorma,” was completed by Franco Alfano.
This grand opera by Alexander Borodin was completed by Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov and Alexander Glazunov.
